docs.lead_paragraph: People with mild to moderate depression can significantly reduce their symptoms if they exercise aerobically, a new study reports. The study appears in the current issue of The American Journal of Preventive Medicine and was led by Dr. Andrea L. Dunn of the Cooper Institute in Golden, Colo.
docs.abstract: Cooper Institute researcher Dr Andrea L Dunn leads study that shows aerobic activity can significantly reduce symptoms of mild to moderate depression in adults; study is published in American Journal of Preventive Medicine (S)
docs.snippet: People with mild to moderate depression can significantly reduce their symptoms if they exercise aerobically, a new study reports.

docs.lead_paragraph: Airborne, a dietary supplement that many people take to help prevent and treat the common cold, is getting a lot of buzz. ''This stuff works,'' a young woman told a stranger in a Times Square pharmacy as she reached for one of the last three packages.

headline.main: Keeping Colds at Bay. Or Maybe Not.

docs.abstract: Cold-prevention supplements, such as Airborne, have become popular despite lack of evidence showing that they have impact on common cold; Dr Eric Larson, Group Health, Seattle, internist, asserts that if documented cold prevention existed then everyone would know about it and doctors would be using it; Airborne contains many well-known vitamins, minerals and herbs often suggested for fighting colds, including vitamin C, zinc, echinacea and garlic; various cold fighting products described; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Doctors say there is so far no evidence to demonstrate that a popular dietary supplement prevents the common cold.

docs.lead_paragraph: Problem drinkers are well known to be at higher risk for the kinds of accidents that send them to the hospital. But a close look at who show up in the emergency room has found an equally strong connection between occasional drinking and injury. Researchers studied more than 2,500 admissions at three Missouri emergency rooms over a two-year period and found that drinking at levels often considered safe was associated with about 4 percent of the injuries reviewed -- about the same level found for patients with an alcohol dependency. The study appears in Annals of Family Medicine and was written by Dr. Maria C. Spurling and Dr. Daniel C. Vinson of the University of Missouri.
docs.abstract: Drs Maria C Spurling and Daniel C Vinson of University of Missouri lead study that shows even moderate drinking increases risk of emergency rooms visits as result of accidents; research, published in Annals of Family Medicine, suggests that moderate drinkers refrain from drinking during leisure time activities that might result in injuries; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: A close look at who shows up in the emergency room has found a strong connection between occasional drinking and injury.

docs.lead_paragraph: The children's cough syrup Triaminic, a staple of family medicine cabinets for decades, has received a coveted seal of approval from the Orthodox Union, the country's largest and most powerful certifier of kosher products for consumers who adhere to Orthodox Judaism's dietary laws. All eight varieties of the liquid decongestant for children now bear the Orthodox Union's trademark label -- the initial U inside an O -- making Triaminic the first over-the-counter medicine to be certified as kosher.

headline.main: Cough Syrup Receives Kosher Seal of Approval

docs.abstract: Triaminic, children's over-the-counter cough medicine, receives seal of approval from Orthodox Union, certifier of kosher products for consumers; Rabbi Eliyahu Safran, union's senior rabbinical coordinator, says estimated 15 to 20 million Americans buy kosher prodcuts and having kosher cough medicine gives parents option for helping children without compromising religious or social beliefs; current and possible future growth in market for kosher products discussed; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The children's cough syrup Triaminic, a staple of family medicine cabinets for decades, has received a coveted seal of approval from the Orthodox Union.

docs.lead_paragraph: My husband's first wife died of breast cancer. Waiting for my biopsy results, after a routine mammogram showed a ''suspicious lesion,'' we tried to defuse the tension by quoting from a column that Thomas L. Friedman wrote in The New York Times shortly after Sept. 11. He told the story of a Lebanese friend who joked that when she got on a plane, she made sure to carry a bomb, because what were the odds of two bombs being there? In our case, there were two bombs. I, too, had breast cancer. It was a bad type caught early; with aggressive treatment the prognosis was good.

headline.main: Who Will Be Next? Pictures From an Epidemic

docs.abstract: Randy S Milden Cases column describes widespread effects of breast cancer on families and communities from her perspective as breast cancer survivor; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: For those living with breast cancer, the magnitude of the epidemic can play a part in shaping our experience.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE CLAIM: Shoveling snow can set off a heart attack. THE FACTS -- As Americans dig their way out of the blizzard that blanketed parts of the Northeast last month, reports of people suffering heart attacks, snow shovel in hand, have surfaced. Many people do not take the risk seriously. But the claim that clearing snow is so strenuous that it can be deadly is no exaggeration, experts say.
docs.abstract: Research shows that shoveling snow can trigger heart attacks in people with no history of cardiovascular disease; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: The claim that clearing snow is so strenuous that it can be deadly is no exaggeration, experts say.

docs.lead_paragraph: More police officers die each year in patrol car crashes than at the hands of criminals, and most of the time the accidents occur when the officers are not speeding to an emergency, a new study says. But the researchers say the number of deaths could be reduced if police departments did more to encourage officers to use seat belts. The authors of the report, in The Journal of Trauma, reviewed hundreds of police car accidents across the country from 1997 to 2001 and also found that officers involved in crashes were 2.6 times as likely to be killed if they were not wearing seat belts.

headline.main: On the Beat: Unbelted and at Risk

docs.abstract: Dr Dietrich von Kuenssberg Jehle, University of Buffalo School of Medicine and Biomedical Sciences researcher, leads study on fatal police car crashes that finds many police do not use seat belt on regular basis; study asserts that 40 percent of police who died in their cars were not wearing seat belts; research, published in Journal of Trauma, suggests installation of passive seat belts to encourage consistent use by police; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: More police officers die each year in patrol car crashes than at the hands of criminals, and most of the time the accidents occur when the officers are not speeding to an emergency, a new study says.

docs.lead_paragraph: Not only red wine but also white wine, beer and hard liquor appear to protect against mental decline in older women, two new studies have found. The studies are the latest to find a benefit from moderate drinking. In one, researchers at Harvard University and Brigham and Women's Hospital followed alcohol consumption among more than 11,000 women enrolled in the Nurses' Health Study, one of the largest investigations into the risk factors for major chronic illnesses in women.

headline.main: Drink a Day May Keep Older Women Sharp

docs.abstract: Recent studies show one half ounce drink per day helps protect against mental decline in older women; Harvard University and Brigham and Women's Hospital researchers followed alcohol consumption among 11,000 women enrolled in Nurses' Health Study and confirmed significantly better mental performance in group of women who consume one drink per day; environmental factors and side benefits of alcohol on women that might influence study findings discussed; researchers suggest more tests should be conducted before non-drinking women are encouraged to start consuming alcohol (S)
docs.snippet: Not only red wine but also white wine, beer and hard liquor appear to protect against mental decline in older women, two new studies have found.

docs.lead_paragraph: At a tattoo and piercing parlor on St. Mark's Place in Manhattan recently, Young-Cho, an experienced tattoo artist, applied a small winged horse to Mara Fallon's shoulder. He dipped his buzzing instrument into a small plastic cup of blue ink and then appeared to draw with the electric needle on Ms. Fallon's shoulder.

headline.main: The Perils Of Needles To the Body

docs.abstract: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention survey finds that one in five college students in Texas have at least one tattoo or body piercing other than ear; health officials warn that tattoos and piercings leave individuals vulnerable to bacterial and viral infection and disfigurement from scarring; research estimates that one in ten piercings becomes infected; suggestions for minimizing risk described; licensing requirements and other preventive health measures discussed (M)
docs.snippet: Health officials say they are increasingly worried about the health risks posed by tattoos and body piercings.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION

docs.lead_paragraph: Younger people may be assumed to be more resilient physically than older people, but when it comes to chronic pain, researchers have found the opposite appears to be the case. A study that looked at the experiences of more than 5,800 patients seeking treatment at a pain center over an eight-year period found that those over 50 tended to bear up better. The study, which appears in the journal Pain Medicine, was written by Dr. Tamara A. Baker of the University of South Florida and Dr. Carmen Renée Green of the University of Michigan.
docs.abstract: University of South Florida researcher Dr Tamara A Baker and Dr Carmen Renee Green of University of Michigan lead study on chronic pain that shows people over 50 are better able to handle pain than younger individuals; study, published in journal Pain Medicine, suggests attitude may play part and older individuals may expect to feel more pain as they age; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Younger people may be assumed to be more resilient physically than older people, but when it comes to chronic pain, researchers have found the opposite appears to be the case.
